abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project shows a
            satisfactory outcome, likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impacts. The integrated approach
            to water quality management - water supply and sanitation
            services, urban upgrading and other basic needs at the local
            levels - is based on multi-sectoral, and inter-institutional
            principles, and is inherently complex. Despite successes,
            and notwithstanding the Bank's 1993 Water Resources
            Policy Paper acknowledging the need for comprehensive water
            resources, planning and management at the river basin level
            (though warning of its difficulties), and the 2003 Water
            Resources Sector Strategy endorsing pragmatic approaches to
            policy reform, in recognition of the political economy of
            changes, difficulties still persist in inter-municipal and
            state-municipal cooperation, and coordination to control
            pollution in highly urbanized river basins. In the final
            analysis, problems related to water quality management,
            pollution control, the environment, and urban upgrading,
            remain complex - both institutionally and in terms of the
            interactions between land uses, infrastructure, pollution,
            and the resulting water quality - which cannot be resolved
            with simple approaches, or isolated sector interventions.
            This experience  demonstrates that a fundamental element of
            such urban water management projects, is the concomitant
            concern with addressing urban poverty and quality of life.
            In response, quality assurance sought to demonstrate an
            approach for comprehensive planning, and management that
            could help overcome the difficulties of coordination, and
            how to achieve effective integration, while demonstrating
            the importance of using the river basin, and sub-basins,
            and, it confirmed that comprehensive urban water resources,
            land-use planning and management, is feasible although
            complex, time consuming, and subject to political risk.
